Pompeio mortuo, liceat multis aliis carere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,033:6:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Lig. 6, 18</bibl></cit>; Sulp. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:4:5:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 4, 5, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:2:1:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 2, 1, 5</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quaerere, qui licuerit aedificare navem senatori,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:5:18:section=45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 5, 18, § 45</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">meamet facta mihi dicere licet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 85:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 85, 24</bibl></cit>.—Without a <hi rend="ital">dat.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">introire in aedes numquam licitum est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:2:1:70" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 2, 1, 70</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">impune optare istuc licet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:3:5:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. 3, 5, 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">modo liceat vivere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:5:2:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Heaut. 5, 2, 28</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">licetne scire ex te?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:5:4:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Hec. 5, 4, 33</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hic subitam rerum commutationem videre licuit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:27:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 3, 27, 1</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">3, 96, 4</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">si facere omnino non licebit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:13:6:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 13, 6, 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">licet ora ipsa cernere iratorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:29:102" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 1, 29, 102</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:41:91" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Div. 1, 41, 91</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">licet hoc videre,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:25:99" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 3, 25, 99</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:7:13" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Div. 1, 7, 13</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,036:1:15:21" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Inv. 1, 15, 21</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 23, 71</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 9, 29</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">veretur ne non liceat tenere hereditatem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:13:48:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 13, 48, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">licetne extra ordinem in provocantem hostem pugnare?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:23:47:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 23, 47, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">poscere ut perculsis instare liceat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:65:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 2, 65, 2</bibl></cit>. —With <hi rend="ital">inf. pass.</hi> (cf. Krebs, Antibarb. p. 660 sq.): <cit><quote lang="la">intellegi jam licet, nullum fore imperium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:1:38:60" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 1, 38, 60</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">idque e pontificio jure intellegi licet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:12:27" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 1, 12, 27</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">his cognosci licuit, quantum, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 3, 28</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:7:20" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 7, 20</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">evocari ex insula Cyprios non licet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:5:21:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 5, 21, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in senatu dici nihil liceat,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 12, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">coöptari sacerdotem licebat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:3:10:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 3, 10, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in eum ordinem coöptari licet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:2:49:section=120" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 2, 49, § 120</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">id primum in poëtis cerni licet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:7:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 3, 7, 27</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ac. 1, 4, 17</bibl>.—The noun of the subject-clause is regularly in the <hi rend="ital">acc.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">licet me id scire quid sit?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:1:1:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ps. 1, 1, 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non licet hominem esse, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:4:1:53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 4, 1, 53</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si licet me latere,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 2, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hocine me miserum non licere meo modo ingenium frui!</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 4, 21</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">eodem ut jure uti senem Liceat, id. Hec. prol. alt. 3: non licet me isto tanto bono uti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:5:59:section=154" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 5, 59, § 154</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum non liceret Romae quemquam esse, etc.,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 2, 41</bibl></cit>, § <cit><quote lang="la">100: ex eis locis, in quibus te habere nihil licet,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 5, 18</bibl></cit>, § <cit><quote lang="la">45: quare licet etiam mortalem esse animum judicantem aeterna moliri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:38:91" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 1, 38, 91</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cur his per te frui libertate sua, cur denique esse liberos non licet?</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fl. 29, 71</bibl></cit> B. and K. (al. liberis; <xr><lbl>v.</lbl> <ref type="sym" targOrder="U">infra</ref></xr>).—So with <hi rend="ital">esse</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">liceat esse miseros,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,033:6:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Lig. 6, 18</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">medios esse jam non licebit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:10:8:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 10, 8, 4</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:5:15:44" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 5, 15, 44</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">1, 38, 91</bibl> Klotz <hi rend="ital">N. cr.;</hi> also with <hi rend="ital">fieri</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut eum liceat ante tempus consulem fieri,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Auct. Her.</author> 3, 2, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut jam liceat una comprehensione omnia complecti non dubitantemque dicere, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:5:9:26" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 5, 9, 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">haec praescripta servantem licet magnifice vivere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:26:92" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 1, 26, 92</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">licet tamen opera prodesse multis, beneficia petentem, etc.,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 19, 67</bibl></cit>.—So with <case>acc.</case> with a <hi rend="ital">subject-inf., esse</hi> or <hi rend="ital">fieri</hi>, even when licet is accompanied by the <hi rend="ital">dat.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">si civi Romano licet esse Gaditanum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,026:12:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Balb. 12, 29</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">potest incidere quaestio, An huic esse procuratorem liceat?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:7:1:19" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 7, 1, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">procuratorem tibi esse non licuit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:4:4:6" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 4, 4, 6</bibl></cit> Zumpt <hi rend="ital">N. cr.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">mihi non licet esse piam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:14:64" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 14, 64</bibl></cit>: is erat annus, quo per leges ei consulem fieri liceret <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 3, 1</bibl> Oud. <hi rend="ital">N. cr.</hi>—But more freq., in this case, there is an attraction of the predicate-noun to the dative dependent on licet.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n26547.3" n="(g)" level="5"> Licet alicui with <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi>, esp. with <hi rend="ital">esse</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">per hanc tibi cenam incenato esse hodie licet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,018:4:2:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Stich. 4, 2, 31</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">per hanc curam quieto tibi licet esse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,009:3:2:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ep. 3, 2, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">licuit esse otioso Themistocli,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:15:33" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 15, 33</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">ut tibi abesse liceat, et esse otioso,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:9:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 9, 2</bibl></cit>, A, 1: quare <pb n="1063" /> <cb n="LICE" /> judici mihi non esse liceat, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,030:7:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rab. Post. 7, 17</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut iis ingratis esse non liceat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:18:63" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 2, 18, 63</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quo in genere mihi neglegenti esse non licet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:1:17:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 1, 17, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cur iis per te frui libertate sua, cur denique esse liberis non licet?</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fl. 29, 71</bibl></cit> (B. and K. liberos; <xr><lbl>v.</lbl> <ref type="sym" targOrder="U">supra</ref></xr>): <cit><quote lang="la">quibus otiosis ne in communi quidem otio liceat esse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,024:1:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cael. 1, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quibus licet jam esse fortunatissimis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:6:35:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 6, 35, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">illis timidis et ignavis licet esse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:44:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 21, 44, 3</bibl></cit>.—With other verbs than <hi rend="ital">esse</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut sibi per te liceat innocenti vitam in egestate degere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:49:144" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Rosc. Am. 49, 144</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum postulasset ... ut sibi triumphanti urbem invehi liceret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:38:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 38, 44 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>— <cit><quote lang="la">Very rarely, in this construction, the dative with licet is wanting, and is to be supplied from the connection: atqui licet esse beatis (sc. iis),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:1:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 1, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">licet eminus esse Fortibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:8:405" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 8, 405</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Hannibal precatur deos ut incolumi cedere atque abire liceat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:26:41:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 26, 41, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sibi vitam filiae suā cariorem fuisse, si liberae ac pudicae vivere licitum fuisset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:50:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 3, 50, 6</bibl></cit>. Cf. on this and the preced. construction, Krüger, Untersuchungen, vol. iii. p. 359 sq.; Ruddim. 2, p. 15; Zumpt, Gram. § 601; Madv. Gram. § 393, c. and obs. 1.—</sense><sense id="n26547.4" n="(d)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">ut</hi>, and more freq. with the simple <hi rend="ital">subj.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">neque jam mihi licet neque est integrum, ut, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,014:4:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Mur. 4, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">facto nunc laedat licet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:2:2:53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 2, 2, 53</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mea quidem causa salvos sis licet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:1:2:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rud. 1, 2, 51</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ludas licet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:2:2:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. 2, 2, 33</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fremant omnes licet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:44:195" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 1, 44, 195</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sed omnia licet concurrant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:14:4:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 14, 4, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ex qua licet pauca degustes,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 16, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vel ipsi hoc dicas licet,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 1, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quamvis licet insectemur istos, metuo ne soli philosophi sint,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:4:24:53" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 4, 24, 53</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:3:10:24" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Leg. 3, 10, 24</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:3:36:88" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 3, 36, 88</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">sequatur Hermagoram licebit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,036:1:51:97" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Inv. 1, 51, 97</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:17:49" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rosc. Am. 17, 49</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">sis pecore et multa dives tellure licebit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,003:15:19" default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Epod. 15, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">detrahat auctori multum fortuna licebit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:5:14:3" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Tr. 5, 14, 3</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:400" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 6, 400</bibl>. Cf. also under II. a.—（<foreign lang="greek">e</foreign>) As a <hi rend="ital">v. impers. absol.</hi>, with or without <hi rend="ital">dat.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">immo, aliis si licet, tibi non licet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:4:15:49" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 4, 15, 49</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum licitum est ei,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:2:6:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> And. 2, 6, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec crederem mihi impunius Licere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:3:2:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Heaut. 3, 2, 50</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quod profecto faciam, si mihi per ejusdem amicitiam licebit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:1:8:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 1, 8, 3</bibl></cit>: <hi rend="ital">Ph.</hi> Sed quaeso, hominem ut jubeas arcessi. <hi rend="ital">He.</hi> Licet, <hi rend="ital">that may be</hi> or <hi rend="ital">may be done, I have no objection</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:5:1:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 5, 1, 29</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">si per vos licet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:prol. 12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> As. prol. 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">id quod postea, si per vos, judices, licitum erit, aperietur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:44:127" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Rosc. Am. 44, 127</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dum per aetatem licet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:1:2:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 1, 2, 28</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fruare, dum licet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:2:3:104" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Heaut. 2, 3, 104</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">dum licet, loquimini mecum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:3:3:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phorm. 3, 3, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sic ut quimus, aiunt, quando, ut volumus, non licet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:4:5:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> And. 4, 5, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut id, quoad posset, quod fas esset, quoad liceret, populi ad partes daret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,011:2:7:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Agr. 2, 7, 19</bibl></cit>.</sense><sense id="n26547.5" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> When licet introduces a subordinate proposition, which makes a concession, without abandoning the main proposition, it is used as a <hi rend="ital">conjunction</hi> corresponding to quamvis, quamquam, etsi. In late Latin it is, like these, connected with the indicative, and in the class. per. it is not unfreq. opposed to tamen and certe in the main proposition; <hi rend="ital">even if, although, notwithstanding</hi>. </sense><sense id="n26547.6" n="A" level="2"> With <hi rend="ital">subj.</hi> (class.): <cit><quote lang="la">quoniam quidem semel suscepi, licet hercules undique omnes mihi minae et terrores periculaque impendeant omnia, succurram atque subibo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:11:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Rosc. Am. 11, 31</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">improbitas, licet adversario molesta sit, judici invisa est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:6:4:15" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 6, 4, 15</bibl></cit>: in comoedia maxime claudamus: licet Varro Musas Plautino dicat sermone locuturas fuisse, si Latine loqui vellent; <cit><quote lang="la">licet, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:10:1:99" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 10, 1, 99</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vita brevis est, licet supra mille annos exeat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Brev. Vit. 6" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Brev. Vit. 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">licet ingens janitor ... exsanguis terreat umbras,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:400" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 6, 400</bibl></cit>. —With <hi rend="ital">part.</hi> for <hi rend="ital">subj.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">isque, licet caeli regione remotos, mente deos adiit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:15:62" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 15, 62</bibl></cit>.—With a corresp. <hi rend="ital">tamen</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">licet laudem Fortunam, tamen, ut ne Salutem culpem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:3:3:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. 3, 3, 28</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">licet saepius tibi hujus generis litteras mittam ... sed tamen, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:13:27:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 13, 27, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">licet tibi significarim, ut ad me venires, tamen, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:3:12:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 3, 12, 3</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:2:2:8" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 2, 2, 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:8:3:69" default="NO">8, 3, 69</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">licet ergo non sint confirmati testamento, a me tamen, ut confirmati, observabuntur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:2:16:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 2, 16, 3</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:7 praef" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 7 praef.</bibl> § 2: constet illi licet fides et benevolentia, tranquillitas tamen, etc., Sen. <cb n="LICI" /> Tranq. Anim. 7, 6.—With <hi rend="ital">ellips. of subj.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">immatura licet, tamen huc non noxia veni (sc. venias),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:5:11:17" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 5, 11, 17</bibl></cit>.—With a corresp. <hi rend="ital">certe</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">licet enim haec quivis arbitratu suo reprehendat ... certe levior reprehensio est,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Ac. 2, 32, 102</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n26547.7" n="B" level="2"> With <hi rend="ital">indic.</hi> (post-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">licet inter gesta et facta videtur quaedam esse subtilis differentia, attamen, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:50:16:58" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 50, 16, 58</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:2:15:8:section=25" default="NO">2, 15, 8, § 25</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">licet directae libertates deficiunt, attamen, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:29:7:2" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 29, 7, 2</bibl></cit>: obduxi licet arma, sum Priapus, Poëta ap. Anth. Lat. 5, 218; <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> S. 1, 11</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 2, p. 117, 25</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n26547.8" n="C" level="2"> As an <pos>adv.</pos> with <pos>adj.</pos> or <hi rend="ital">part., although</hi> (post-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">licet contumacissimum, tamen efficacissimum, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Cons. ad Marc. 8:1" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Cons. ad Marc. 8, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">miles, licet membris vigentibus firmus, se solum circumspicit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 14, 10, 12</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">17, 12, 11</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Claud. Mam.</author> Paneg. Max. 1</bibl>.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n26547.9" n="1" level="3"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">lĭcens</orth>, <itype>entis</itype>, <hi rend="ital">P. a., free, unrestrained, uncurbed, bold, forward, presumptuous, licentious</hi>. </sense><sense id="n26547.10" n="A" level="2"> Of persons (only <usg type="style">poet.</usg> and in post-class. prose): <cit><quote lang="la">quam audaces et quam licentes sumus qui, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:15:9:4" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 15, 9, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">unde licens Fabius sacra Lupercus habet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:4:1:26" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 4, 1, 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">turba licens, Naides improbae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Hippol. 777" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Hippol. 777</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n26547.11" n="B" level="2"> Of inanim. and abstr. things (once in Cic.; elsewh. only <usg type="style">poet.</usg> and in post-Aug. prose): <cit><quote lang="la">licentior dithyrambus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:48:185" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 3, 48, 185</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hic tibi multa licet sermone licentia tecto Dicere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,004:1:569" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> A. A. 1, 569</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">joci,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,002:1:6:93" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> S. 1, 6, 93</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">licentior epistula, Plin. N. H. prooem. § 1: imperium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:6:4:2" default="NO"><author>Val. Max.</author> 6, 4, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vita,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:9:1:3" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 9, 1, 3</bibl></cit>. —Hence, <pos>adv.</pos>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">lĭcenter</orth>, <hi rend="ital">freely, according to one's own pleasure</hi> or <hi rend="ital">fancy;</hi> and, in a bad sense, <hi rend="ital">without restraint, boldly, impudently, licentiously</hi> (class.): <cit><quote lang="la">at quam licenter!</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:39:109" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 1, 39, 109</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut ingredi libere, non ut licenter videatur errare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:23:77" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Or. 23, 77</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Graeci licenter multa,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:1:8:6" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 1, 8, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquid facere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:26:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 26, 10</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">(servos) licentius, liberius, familiarius cum domina vivere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,024:23:57" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cael. 23, 57</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Romanos, remoto metu, laxius licentiusque futuros,</quote> <trans><tr>more remiss in their discipline</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 87" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 87 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">gerere res communes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:ib. 108" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> ib. 108</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ausi aliquid,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:2:4:14" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 2, 4, 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si quid licentius dixerint,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:1:2:7" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 1, 2, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">translata,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:8:3:37" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 8, 3, 37</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:12:10:50" default="NO">12, 10, 50</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Liberum et Cererem pro vino et pane licentius, quam ut fori severitas ferat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:8:6:24" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 8, 6, 24</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:6:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 6, 13</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n26547.12" n="2" level="3"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">lĭcĭtus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <hi rend="ital">P. a., permitted, allowed, allowable, lawful</hi> (<usg type="style">poet.</usg> and post-Aug. for permissus, honestus): <cit><quote lang="la">sermo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:8:468" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 8, 468</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">torus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Petr.</author> 34, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">acies,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:11:123" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 11, 123</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">negotiatio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:37:14:2" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 37, 14, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">contractus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:50:14:3" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 50, 14, 3</bibl></cit>.—In <number>plur.</number> as <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">lĭcĭta</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">things that are lawful</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ipse per licita atque illicita foedatus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:15:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 15, 37</bibl></cit>.—Hence, <pos>adv.</pos>, in two forms: <orth extent="full" lang="la">lĭcĭtē</orth> and <orth extent="full" lang="la">lĭcĭtō</orth>, <hi rend="ital">rightfully, lawfully</hi> (post-class. for juste, honeste, legitime).—Form licite, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:30:114:section=5" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 30, 114, § 5</bibl>.— <cit><quote lang="la">Form licito,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Sol.</author> 11, 8</bibl></cit>; Cod. Th. 11, 8, 3.</sense></entryFree>
lichanos: <entryFree id="n26548" type="greek" key="li^cha^nos"><orth extent="full" lang="la">lĭchănos</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">li/xanos</foreign>, <sense id="n26548.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a note on the tetrachord</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:5:4:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 5, 4, 5</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
lichas: <entryFree id="n26549" type="main" key="Li^chas"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Lĭchas</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*li/xas</foreign>, <sense id="n26549.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an attendant of Hercules, who brought to him the poisoned garment of Dejanira</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:9:155" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 9, 155</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">211</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">229</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0533,001:Fab. 36" default="NO"><author>Hyg.</author> Fab. 36</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
lichen: <entryFree id="n26550" type="greek" key="li_che_n"><orth extent="full" lang="la">līchēn</orth>, <itype>ēnis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">leixh/n</foreign>, <sense id="n26550.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a cryptogamic species of vegetation growing on trees, lichen</hi>. </sense><sense id="n26550.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:26:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 26, 4, 10, § 21</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n26550.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">an eruption on the skin of men and beasts, a tetter, ringworm</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">in fricando lichene,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:23:118" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 23, 7, 63, § 118</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sordidi lichenes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:11:98:5" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 11, 98, 5</bibl></cit>.—Of beasts, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:30:88" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 30, 10, 27, § 88</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n26550.3" n="B" level="2"> Esp., <hi rend="ital">a callous excrescence upon the leg of a horse, used as a medicine</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">lichene equi cum oleo infuso per aurem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:28:180" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 28, 11, 49, § 180</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:28:230" default="NO" valid="yes">28, 17, 67, § 230</bibl> saep.</sense></entryFree>
liciatorium: <entryFree id="n26551" type="main" key="li_ci^a_to_ri^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">līcĭātōrĭum</orth>, ii. <gen>n.</gen> <etym>licium</etym>, <sense id="n26551.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a weaver's beam</hi> (late Lat.): <cit><quote lang="la">liciatorium texentium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,011:17:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 1 Reg. 17, 7</bibl></cit> al.</sense></entryFree>
liciatus: <entryFree id="n26552" type="main" key="li_ci^a_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">līcĭātus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>licium; laid, leashed, like a web; hence, trop.</etym>, <sense id="n26552.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">begun, commenced</hi> (late Lat.): ut ita dicam liciatum videtur, quod nondum est, Aug. Civ. Dei, 22, 14; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:ad Litt. 3:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Gen. ad Litt. 3, 14</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
licinianus: <entryFree id="n26553" type="main" key="Li^ci^ni^a_nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Lĭcĭnĭānus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, v. Licinius, II. B.</entryFree>
licinio: <entryFree id="n26554" type="main" key="li_ci^ni^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">līcĭnĭo</orth>, <itype>āre, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>licium</etym>, <sense id="n26554.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to show through, disclose</hi>, of a thin texture: <cit><quote lang="la">membrorum voluptatem,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 10, p. 254, 11</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
licinium: <entryFree id="n26555" type="main" key="li_ci^ni^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">līcĭnĭum</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n26555.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">lint</hi> for dressing wounds (late Lat.), <bibl default="NO"><author>Veg.</author> Vet. 2, 22, 2</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 48, 6</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
licinius: <entryFree id="n26556" type="main" key="Li^ci^ni^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Lĭcĭnĭus</orth>, <itype>a</itype>, <sense id="n26556.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">name of a Roman</hi> gens. <cb n="LICI" /> </sense><sense id="n26556.1" n="1" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">The tribune</hi> C. Licinius Crassus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 1:2:9" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 1, 2, 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:25:96" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Lael. 25, 96</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n26556.2" n="2" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">The triumvir</hi> M. Licinius Crassus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:2:9:22" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 2, 9, 22</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:6:465" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 6, 465</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n26556.3" n="3" level="3"> L. Licinius Crassus, <hi rend="ital">the famous orator</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:20:74" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 3, 20, 74</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,003:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> Dial. 34</bibl>.—In <hi rend="ital">fem.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Lĭcĭnĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <hi rend="ital">a daughter of the orator</hi> L. Licinius Crassus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:58:211" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 58, 211</bibl>.—Also, <hi rend="ital">a vestal</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:43:160" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 43, 160</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n26556.4" n="II" level="1"> Hence, </sense><sense id="n26556.5" n="A" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Lĭcĭnĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <hi rend="ital">adj., of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to a Licinius, Licinian</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">lex, of various kinds, esp. the lex de sodaliciis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,028:15:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Planc. 15, 36</bibl></cit>; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">the Index legum, Orell. Cic. Opera, vol. viii. p. 199 sq.: lex Licinia et Mucia de civibus redigundis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Cornel. Fragm. 10</bibl></cit>, vol. xi. p. 11 B. and K.: <cit><quote lang="la">lex de modo agrorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:34:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 34, 4</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 1:2:9 al" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 1, 2, 9 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">atria, named after L. Licinius Crassus,</quote> <trans><tr>auction-halls</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Quint. 3, 12</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">6, 25</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n26556.6" n="B" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Lĭcĭnĭānus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <hi rend="ital">adj., Licinian</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">olea,</quote> <trans><tr>introduced by a Licinius</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cato</author>, R. R. 6, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">jugera,</quote> <trans><tr>the lands distributed to the plebeians by C. Licinius Stolo</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:1:3:10" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 1, 3, 10</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:Arb. 17" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Arb. 17</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n26556.7" n="2" level="3"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Lĭcĭ-nĭāni</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">a surname of the sons and descendants of Cato the Censor, by his first wife</hi>, Licinia; <cit><quote lang="la">to distinguish them from those by the second, who where called Salonii or Saloniani,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:7:62" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 7, 14, 12, § 62</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
licinus: <entryFree id="n26557" type="main" key="li^ci^nus1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">lĭcĭnus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <sense id="n26557.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">adj., bent</hi> or <hi rend="ital">turned upward</hi>: Licini boves (i. e. qui sursum versum reflexa cornua habent), Serv. and Philarg. on <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:3:55" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 3, 55</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n26558" type="main" key="Li^ci^nus2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Lĭcĭnus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n26558.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a surname in the</hi> gens Fabia <hi rend="ital">and</hi> Porcia.—Also, <hi rend="ital">the name of a barber and freedman of Augustus, celebrated for his wealth</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,006:301" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> A. P. 301</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:8:3:6" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 8, 3, 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:Atac. in Anth. Lat. T. 1, p. 205" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> Atac. in Anth. Lat. T. 1, p. 205</bibl>. —<hi rend="ital">Plur.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ego possideo plus Pallante et Licinis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:1:109" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 1, 109</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
licitatio: <entryFree id="n26559" type="main" key="li^ci^ta_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">lĭcĭtātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>licitor</etym>, <sense id="n26559.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an offering of a price, a bidding</hi> for any thing, at sales and auctions: <cit><quote lang="la">exquisitis palam pretiis et licitationibus factis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:2:53:section=133" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 2, 53, § 133</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:11:15:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 11, 15, 4</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">praedam ad licitationem dividere,</quote> <trans><tr>to the highest bidders</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=nero:26" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Ner. 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">licitatione maxima comparare aliquid,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cal.:22" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Calig. 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad licitationem rem deducere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:10:2:6" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 10, 2, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">licitatione vincere,</quote> <trans><tr>to bid highest</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:10:2:6" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 10, 2, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">penes quem licitatio remansit,</quote> <trans><tr>to whom it was knocked down</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:10:3:19" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 10, 3, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum contentio fructus licitationis est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1251,001:Inst. 4:244" default="NO"><author>Gai.</author> Inst. 4, 244</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
licitator: <entryFree id="n26560" type="spur" key="li^ci^ta_tor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">lĭcĭtātor</orth>, <itype>ōris, an old erroneous reading for illicitator</itype>, v. h. v., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:15:61" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 3, 15, 61</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:7:2:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 7, 2, 1</bibl>.</entryFree>
licite: <entryFree id="n26561" type="main" key="li^ci^te_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">lĭcĭtē</orth> and <orth extent="full" lang="la">lĭcĭtō</orth>, <sense id="n26561.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">advv.</hi>, v. licet <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi> B.</sense></entryFree>
licitor: <entryFree id="n26562" type="main" key="li^ci^tor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">lĭcĭtor</orth>, <itype>ātus, 1</itype>, <pos>v. dep.</pos> <etym>liceor</etym>, <sense id="n26562.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to offer a price, to bid</hi> for any thing (ante- and postclass.). </sense><sense id="n26562.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut ne licitare advorsum animi mei sententiam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,011:2:3:104" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Merc. 2, 3, 104</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n26562.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to contend, fight</hi>: licitati in mercando sive pugnando contendentes, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=116" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 116</bibl> Müll.: inter se licitantur, Enn. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 134, 14</bibl> (Ann. v. 77 Vahl.): licitari machaerā adversum aliquem, Caecil. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 134, 16</bibl> (Com. Fragm. v. 69 Rib.).</sense></entryFree>
licitus: <entryFree id="n26563" type="main" key="li^ci^tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">lĭcĭtus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, v. licet <sense id="n26563.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi> B.</sense></entryFree>
licium: <entryFree id="n26564" type="main" key="li_cium"><orth extent="full" lang="la">līcium</orth>, <itype>ĭi</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <sense id="n26564.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the thrum</hi> or <hi rend="ital">leash</hi>, the ends of a web to which those of the new piece are fastened. </sense><sense id="n26564.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">licia telae Addere,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>to weave</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:1:285" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 1, 285</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adnectit licia telis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:1:6:79" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 1, 6, 79</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">plurimis liciis texere, quae polymita appellant, Alexandria instituit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:8:196" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 8, 48, 74, § 196</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n26564.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n26564.3" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A thread of the web</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">per licia texta querelas Edidit et tacitis mandavit crimina telis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Aus.</author> Ep. 23, 14</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n26564.4" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A thread</hi> of any thing woven: <cit><quote lang="la">licia dependent longas velantia sepes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:3:267" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 3, 267</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cinerem fici cum aluta inligatum licio e collo suspendere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:23:125" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 23, 7, 63, § 125</bibl></cit>.—Often used in charms and spells: <cit><quote lang="la">tum cantata ligat cum fusco licia rhombo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:2:575" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 2, 575</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">terna tibi haec primum triplici diversa colore Licia circumdo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:8:73" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 8, 73</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:28:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 28, 4, 12, § 48</bibl>.—As an ornament for the head, worn by women: licia crinibus addunt, Prud. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:2:1104" default="NO"><author>Symm.</author> 2, 1104</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n26564.5" n="C" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A small girdle</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belt around the abdomen;</hi> so in the law phrase: per lancem et licium furta concipere, i. e. <hi rend="ital">to search in a house for stolen property;</hi> this was done per licium, with which the person making the search was covered, and per lancem, which he held before his face, in order not to be recognized by the women. This lanx was perforated. He was clothed <pb n="1064" /> <cb n="LIEN" /> with a licium instead of his usual garments, that he might not be suspected of having brought in his clothes that which he might find and recognize as stolen property, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:11:18:9" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 11, 18, 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:16:10" default="NO">16, 10</bibl>; v. lanx.</sense></entryFree>
lictor: <entryFree id="n26565" type="main" key="lictor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">lictor</orth> (pronounced līctor, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:12:3:4" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 12, 3, 4</bibl>), <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>1. ligo; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:12:3:1" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 12, 3, 1</bibl> sqq.</etym>, <sense id="n26565.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a lictor</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">an attendant granted to a magistrate, as a sign of official dignity</hi>. The Romans adopted this custom from the Etrurians: <cit><quote lang="la">Romulus cum cetero habitu se augustiorem tum maxime lictoribus duodecim sumptis (a finitima Etruria) fecit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 8</bibl></cit>. The lictors bore a bundle of rods, from which an axe projected. Their duty was to walk before the magistrate in a line, one after the other; to call out to the people to make way (submovere turbam); <cit><quote lang="la">and to remind them of paying their respects to him (animadvertere, v. h. v.). The foremost one was called primus lictor: apud quem primus quievit lictor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,058:1:1:7:section=21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Q. Fr. 1, 1, 7, § 21</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">the last and nearest to the consul, proximus lictor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:24:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 24, 44 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit> The lictors had also to execute sentences of judgment, to bind criminals to a stake, to scourge them, and to behead them, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 26</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:8:7" default="NO" valid="yes">8, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:38" default="NO" valid="yes">38</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">26, 16.—It was necessary that lictors should be freeborn: not till the time of Tacitus were freedmen also appointed to the office. They were united into a company, and formed the decuriae apparitorum (public servants). In Rome they wore the toga, in the field the sagum, in triumphal processions a purple mantle and fasces wreathed with laurel: togulae lictoribus ad portam praesto fuerunt, quibus illi acceptis, sagula rejecerunt et catervam imperatori suo novam praebuerunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:23:55" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Pis. 23, 55</bibl></cit>. Only those magistrates who had potestatem cum imperio had lictors. In the earliest times the king had twelve; immediately after the expulsion of the kings, each of the two consuls had twelve; <cit><quote lang="la">but it was soon decreed that the consuls should be preceded for a month alternately by twelve lictors,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 1</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">a regulation which appears to have been afterwards, although not always, observed,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:22:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 22, 41</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">Cæsar was the first who restored the old custom,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:20" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 20</bibl></cit>.—The decemvirs had, in their first year of office, twelve lictors each one day alternately, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 33</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">in their second year each had twelve lictors to himself,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 3, 36</bibl></cit>.— <cit><quote lang="la">The military tribunes with consular power had also twelve lictors,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 4, 7</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">and likewise the interrex,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 1, 17</bibl></cit>.—The dictator had twenty-four, Dio, 54, 1; Polyb. 3, 87; Plut. Fab. 4; <cit><quote lang="la">the magister equitum only six, Dio, 42, 27. The praetor urbanus had, in the earlier times, two lictors,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Censor.</author> de Die Natal. 24</bibl></cit>: at enim unum a praetura tua, Epidice, abest. <hi rend="ital">Ep.</hi> Quidnam? <hi rend="ital">Th.</hi> Scies. Lictores duo, duo viminei fasces virgarum, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,009:1:1:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ep. 1, 1, 26</bibl>; in the provinces he had six; <cit><quote lang="la">but in the later times the praetor had in the city, as well as in the province, six lictors, Polyb. 3, 40: cum praetor lictorem impellat et ire praecipitem jubeat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:3:128" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 3, 128</bibl></cit>. The quaestor had lictors only in the province, when he, in consequence of the praetor's absence or death, performed the functions of propraetor, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 19</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,028:41:98" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Planc. 41, 98</bibl>. Moreover, the flamen dialis, the vestals, and the magistri vicorum had lictors; <cit><quote lang="la">these, however, appear to have had no fasces, which was also the case with the thirty lictores curiati (who summoned the curiae to vote),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,011:2:12:81" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Agr. 2, 12, 81</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:15:27:2" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 15, 27, 2</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Grut.</author> 33, 4</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">630, 9</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n26565.1" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">lictorem feminae in publico unionem esse,</quote> <trans><tr>a lady's mark of distinction</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:9:114" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 9, 35, 56, § 114</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
lictorius: <entryFree id="n26566" type="main" key="licto_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">lictōrĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>lictor</etym>, <sense id="n26566.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to a lictor</hi> (post-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">virga lictoria,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:1:26:3" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 1, 26, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">DECVRIA LICTORIA,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 2676</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fasces,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:Vir. Ill. 20:1" default="NO"><author>Aur. Vict.</author> Vir. Ill. 20, 1</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
licus: <entryFree id="n26567" type="main" key="Li^cus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Lĭcus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n26567.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a river in Vindelicia, a tributary of the Danube</hi>, now the <hi rend="ital">Lech</hi>, Ven. Vit. S. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:4:641" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 4, 641</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
lien: <entryFree id="n26568" type="main" key="li^e_n"><orth extent="full" lang="la">lĭēn</orth>, <itype>ēnis</itype>, and <orth extent="full" lang="la">liēnis</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> (<sense id="n26568.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">gen. plur.</hi> lienum, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:23:121" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 23, 7, 63, § 121</bibl>) [for plien; Sanscr. plīhan; Gr. <foreign lang="greek">splh/n</foreign>], <hi rend="ital">the milt</hi> or <hi rend="ital">spleen</hi>. </sense><sense id="n26568.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">lienes turgent, Cato. R. R. 157: seditionem facit lien (of a stitch in the side),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,011:1:2:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Merc. 1, 2, 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">jam quasi sona liene cinctus ambulo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,008:2:1:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Curc. 2, 1, 6</bibl></cit>: equisetum lienes cursorum exstinguit,<cb n="LIGN" />  <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:26:132" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 26, 13, 83, § 132</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">at lienis, ubi affectus est, intumescit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:4:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 4, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">lienis bubulus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:ib" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> ib.</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">lienem coërcere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:ib" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> ib.</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">extenuare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:ib" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> ib.</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">consumere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:26:76" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 26, 8, 48, § 76</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n26568.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, of the fiscus: <cit><quote lang="la">(Trajanus) fiscum lienem vocavit, quod eo crescente artus reliqui tabescunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:Epit. 42" default="NO"><author>Aur. Vict.</author> Epit. 42 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit></sense></entryFree>
lienicus: <entryFree id="n26569" type="main" key="li^e_ni^cus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">lĭēnĭcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>lien</etym>, = <foreign lang="greek">splhniko/s</foreign>, <sense id="n26569.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">splenetic.—Subst.</hi> </sense><sense id="n26569.1" n="A" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">lĭēnĭci</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">splenetic persons</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2305,001:Tard. 3:4:56" default="NO"><author>Cael. Aur.</author> Tard. 3, 4, 56</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2305,001:57" default="NO">57</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2305,001:64" default="NO">64</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n26569.2" n="B" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">lĭēnĭca</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">remedies for spleen</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2305,001:Tard. 3:4:58" default="NO"><author>Cael. Aur.</author> Tard. 3, 4, 58</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
lienosus: <entryFree id="n26570" type="main" key="li^e_no_sus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">lĭēnōsus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n26570.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">splenetic</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cor lienosum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,006:2:6:62" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Cas. 2, 6, 62</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Plur.</hi> as <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">tactu lienosis medebatur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:7:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 7, 2, 2, § 20</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
lientericus: <entryFree id="n26571" type="main" key="li_ente^ri^cus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">līentĕrĭcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym><foreign lang="greek">leienteri/a</foreign>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:2:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 2, 1</bibl></etym>, <sense id="n26571.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">troubled with looseness</hi> or <hi rend="ital">diarrhœa, lienteric</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">dantur coeliacis ... sic et lientericis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:29:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 29, 3, 11, § 44</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
ligamen: <entryFree id="n26572" type="main" key="li^ga_men"><orth extent="full" lang="la">lĭgāmen</orth>, <itype>ĭnis</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>1. ligo</etym>, <sense id="n26572.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a band, tie, bandage</hi> (<usg type="style">poet.</usg> and in post-Aug. prose): <cit><quote lang="la">Sidoniae nocturna ligamina mitrae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:2:22:15" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 2, 22, 15</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:14:230" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 14, 230</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ligamina vitium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:11:2:92" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 11, 2, 92</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ligamina herbarum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:12:8:1" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 12, 8, 1</bibl></cit>.—In <number>sing.</number>: <cit><quote lang="la">papyri ligamen,</quote> <trans><tr>a bandage, ligature</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:6:6:4" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 6, 6, 4</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
ligamentum: <entryFree id="n26573" type="main" key="li^ga_mentum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">lĭgāmentum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n26573.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a band, tie, bandage</hi> (post - Aug.): <cit><quote lang="la">aurium ligamenta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:11:3:144" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 11, 3, 144</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vulneribus ligamenta parare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:15:54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 15, 54</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
ligarius: <entryFree id="n26574" type="main" key="Li^ga_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Lĭgārĭus</orth>, <itype>a</itype>, <sense id="n26574.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">name of a Roman</hi> gens. So, Q. Ligarius, <hi rend="ital">whom Cicero defended in an oration still extant</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:11:1:80" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 11, 1, 80</bibl>; Auct. B. Afr. 64, 1; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,033:1:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Lig. 1, 1</bibl>.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n26574.1" n="II" level="1"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Lĭgārĭānus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <hi rend="ital">adj., of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to Ligarius, Ligarian</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">oratio Ligariana,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:13:44:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 13, 44, 3</bibl></cit>; or <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Lĭ-gārĭāna</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">Cicero's oration for Ligarius</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:13:19:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 13, 19, 2</bibl>.—Also <number>plur.</number>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Lĭ-gārĭāna</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, the same, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:13:12:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 13, 12, 2</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
ligatio: <entryFree id="n26575" type="main" key="li^ga_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">lĭgātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>1. ligo</etym>, <sense id="n26575.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a binding</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2305,001:Acut. 2:37:195" default="NO"><author>Cael. Aur.</author> Acut. 2, 37, 195</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1011,001:Comp. 255" default="NO"><author>Scrib.</author> Comp. 255</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
ligatura: <entryFree id="n26576" type="main" key="li^ga_tu_ra"><orth extent="full" lang="la">lĭgātūra</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n26576.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a band, ligature</hi> (post-class.). </sense><sense id="n26576.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">ligatura in vitibus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Pall.</author> 1, 6, 11</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n26576.2" n="B" level="2"> In partic., <hi rend="ital">an amulet</hi> (bound about one), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2468,001:in Joann. 7" default="NO"><author>Aug.</author> in Joann. 7</bibl>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Isid.</author> Orig. 8, 9</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n26576.3" n="C" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A bunch, cluster</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">duas ligaturas uvae passae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,011:30:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 1 Reg. 30, 12</bibl></cit>.— —</sense><sense id="n26576.4" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">a twisting</hi> or <hi rend="ital">twining</hi> of the body in wrestling: <cit><quote lang="la">ligaturis corporis certant,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Ambros.</author> Enarrat. in Psa. 36, § 55</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
ligauni: <entryFree id="n26577" type="main" key="Li^gauni"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Lĭgauni</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n26577.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a people of</hi> Gallia Narbonensis, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:4:206" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 4, 206</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
ligdus: <entryFree id="n26578" type="main" key="Li^gdus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Lĭgdus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">Lygdus</orth>), <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n26578.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a Cretan, the husband of Telethusa, and father of Iphis, who, on the day of her wedding, was turned into a man</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:9:669:683" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 9, 669, 683</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
ligea: <entryFree id="n26579" type="main" key="Li^ge_a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Lĭgēa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*li/geia</foreign> (clear-voiced). <sense id="n26579.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A wood-nymph, dryad</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:4:336" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 4, 336</bibl>.— </sense><sense id="n26579.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">An island opposite the Bruttian town Tempsa</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Sol.</author> 2</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
ligella: <entryFree id="n26580" type="main" key="Li^gella"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Lĭgella</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n26580.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the name of a woman</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:10:90" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 10, 90</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
liger: <entryFree id="n26581" type="main" key="Li^ger"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Lĭger</orth>, <itype>ĕris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n26581.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a river forming the boundary between</hi> Gallia Lugdunensis <hi rend="ital">and</hi> Aquitania, now the <hi rend="ital">Loire</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quod Liger ex nivibus creverat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:7:55:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 7, 55, 10</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:1:7:12" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 1, 7, 12</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum ad flumen Ligerim venissent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:7:5:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 7, 5, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Caesar Ligere interclusus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 7, 59</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in flumine Ligeri,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 9</bibl></cit>.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n26581.1" n="II" level="1"> ‡ <orth extent="full" lang="la">Lĭgerĭcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <hi rend="ital">adj., of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to the Liger, Ligerian</hi>, Inscr. ap. Grut. 472, 1.</sense></entryFree>
ligii: <entryFree id="n26582" type="main" key="Ligii"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ligii</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">Lygii</orth>), <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n26582.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a Germanic people on the Weser</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,002:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> G. 43</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:12:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 12, 29</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">30</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
lignarius: <entryFree id="n26583" type="main" key="ligna_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">lignārĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>lignum</etym>, <sense id="n26583.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to wood, wood-</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">negotiatio,</quote> <trans><tr>timbertrade</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Capitol.</author> Pert. 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">lima,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1011,001:Comp. 141" default="NO"><author>Scrib.</author> Comp. 141</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">artifex,</quote> <trans><tr>a worker in wood</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,048:44:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Isa. 44, 13</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n26583.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">lignārĭus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> </sense><sense id="n26583.2" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A worker in wood, a carpenter, joiner</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Pall.</author> 1, 6, 2</bibl>.—Perh. hence, </sense><sense id="n26583.3" n="2" level="3"> Inter lignarios, <hi rend="ital">a place in Rome</hi> before the Porta Trigemina, perh. <hi rend="ital">Joiners'-street, Timber-street</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:35:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 35, 41 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl> (acc. to others, <hi rend="ital">timber-market</hi>).—</sense><sense id="n26583.4" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A slave whose office it was to carry wood</hi> (to a temple), <hi rend="ital">a wood-carrier</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Josue Gabionitas in aquarios lignariosque damnavit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hier.</author> Ep. 108, 8</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n26583.5" n="C" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A wood-cutter, woodman</hi>: lignarius <foreign lang="greek">culoko/pos, o( ko/ptwn cu/la</foreign>, Gloss. Lat. Gr. <cb n="LIGO" /></sense></entryFree>
lignatio: <entryFree id="n26584" type="main" key="ligna_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">lignātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>lignor</etym>, <sense id="n26584.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a felling</hi> or <hi rend="ital">procuring of wood</hi>. </sense><sense id="n26584.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui lignationis munitionisque causā in silvas discessissent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:5:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 5, 38</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quae maxime necessaria est ad cibum excoquendum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:5:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 5, 9 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n26584.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, concr., <hi rend="ital">a place where wood is cut, a place for procuring wood</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:1:5:1" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 1, 5, 1</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
lignator: <entryFree id="n26585" type="main" key="ligna_tor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">lignātor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n26585.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a wood-cutter, one sent to get wood</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">oppressis lignatoribus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:5:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 5, 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">legio tertia, quae pabulatores et lignatores tueretur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:41:1:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 41, 1, 7</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
ligneolus: <entryFree id="n26586" type="main" key="ligne^o^lus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">lignĕŏlus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <sense id="n26586.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">adj. dim.</hi> [ligneus], <hi rend="ital">wooden</hi>, of small objects: scuta, Lucil. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> 3 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">lychnuchus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,058:3:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Q. Fr. 3, 7</bibl></cit>: figurae, App. de Mundo, p. 70, 19.</sense></entryFree>
ligneus: <entryFree id="n26587" type="main" key="ligne^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">lignĕus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>lignum</etym>, <sense id="n26587.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of wood, wooden</hi>. </sense><sense id="n26587.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">ponticulus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:5:20:59" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 5, 20, 59</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">turres,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 3, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">materia,</quote> <trans><tr>wood</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,036:2:57:170" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Inv. 2, 57, 170</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">deus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:1:11:20" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 1, 11, 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">piscinas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:34:123" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 34, 12, 32, § 123</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Fabii Maximi oppida,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:6:3:61" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 6, 3, 61</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">custodia,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>the stocks</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:5:6:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Poen. 5, 6, 28</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">salus,</quote> <trans><tr>written on wooden tablets</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:1:1:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ps. 1, 1, 45</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n26587.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n26587.3" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Like wood, woody</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">putamen,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:15:86" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 15, 22, 24, § 86</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">semen (arboris),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:16:110" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 16, 26, 46, § 110</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n26587.4" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Like dry wood, dry</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nervosa et lignea (appellatur) dorcas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:1161" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 4, 1161</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">conjux,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:23:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 23, 6</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
lignicida: <entryFree id="n26588" type="spur" key="ligni^ci_da"><orth extent="full" lang="la">lignĭcīda</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>lignum-caedo</etym>, <sense id="n26588.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">one who cuts</hi> or <hi rend="ital">hews wood</hi>, not used, and only analogously formed by <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 8:section=62" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 8, § 62</bibl> Müll.</sense></entryFree>
lignifer: <entryFree id="n26589" type="gloss" key="ligni^fer"><orth extent="full" lang="la">lignĭfer</orth>, <itype>fĕri</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>lignum-fero</etym>, <sense id="n26589.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">one who carries wood</hi> or <hi rend="ital">a tree</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 4138</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
lignor: <entryFree id="n26590" type="main" key="lignor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">lignor</orth>, <itype>ātus, 1</itype>, <pos>v. dep.</pos> <etym>lignum</etym>, <sense id="n26590.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to fetch</hi> or <hi rend="ital">procure wood, to collect wood</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">num lignatum mittimur?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:3:4:125" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 3, 4, 125</bibl></cit> (dub.; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">Brix ad loc.): lignandi atque aquandi potestas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 3, 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">lignandi pabulandique causā progredi,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 76, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">lignatum ire,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:40:25:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 40, 25, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">procul a castris lignatum pabulatumque progressi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:25:34:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 25, 34, 4</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
lignosus: <entryFree id="n26591" type="main" key="ligno_sus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">lignōsus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n26591.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">like wood, woody</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">caules,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:25:65" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 25, 6, 29, § 65</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">glutinum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:28:236" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 28, 17, 71, § 236</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">lignosiora sunt reliqua,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:19:88" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 19, 5, 27, § 88</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n26591.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Stony, having a large stone</hi> or <hi rend="ital">kernel</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">fructus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:24:69" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 24, 9, 42, § 69</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nucleus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:13:112" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 13, 19, 34, § 112</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
lignum: <entryFree id="n26592" type="main" key="lignum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">lignum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>prob. root leg-, v. 2. lĕgo; that which is gathered, i. e. for firewood</etym>, <sense id="n26592.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">wood</hi> (<hi rend="ital">firewood.</hi> opp. to materia, timber for building, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:32:1:55" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 32, 1, 55</bibl>). </sense><sense id="n26592.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> (class. only in <number>plur.</number>): <cit><quote lang="la">ligna neque fumosa erunt et ardebunt bene,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cato</author>, R. R. 130</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ligna et sarmenta circumdare, ignem subicere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:1:27:section=69" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 1, 27, § 69</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ignem ex lignis viridibus atque umidis fieri jussit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 1, 17</bibl></cit>, § <cit><quote lang="la">45: ligna super foco Large reponens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:9:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 9, 5</bibl></cit>: ligna et virgas et carbones quibusdam videri esse in penu, Mas. Sab. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:4:1:22" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 4, 1, 22</bibl>.—Prov.: in silvam ligna ferre, i. e. <hi rend="ital">to perform useless labor</hi>, or, as we say in English, <hi rend="ital">to carry coals to Newcastle</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:10:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 10, 34</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">lignorum aliquid posce,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:7:24" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 7, 24</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n26592.2" n="B" level="2"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">timber, wood</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">hos lignum stabat in usus, Annosam si forte nucem dejecerat Eurus,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>for making tables</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:11:118" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 11, 118</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n26592.3" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n26592.4" n="A" level="2"> That which is made of wood, <hi rend="ital">a writing-tablet</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">vana supervacui dicunt chirographa ligni,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:13:137" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 13, 137</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:16:41" default="NO">16, 41</bibl>; <hi rend="ital">a plank</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ventis animam committe, dolato confisus ligno,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:12:58" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 12, 58</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n26592.5" n="B" level="2"> The hard part of fruit, <hi rend="ital">the shell</hi> (of a nut), or the <hi rend="ital">stone</hi> or <hi rend="ital">kernel</hi> (of cherries, plums, etc.): <cit><quote lang="la">bacarum intus lignum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:15:111" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 15, 28, 34, § 111</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:15:10" default="NO" valid="yes">15, 3, 3, § 10</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">lignum in pomo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:13:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 13, 4, 9, § 40</bibl></cit>; of <hi rend="ital">grape-stones</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:17:162" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 17, 21, 35, § 162</bibl>.— </sense><sense id="n26592.6" n="C" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A fault in table-tops, where the grain of the wood is not curly, but straight</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:13:98" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 13, 15, 30, § 98</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n26592.7" n="D" level="2"> (<usg type="style">Poet.</usg> and late Lat.) <hi rend="ital">A tree</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:12:767" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 12, 767</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:8:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 8, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:2:13:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> C. 2, 13, 11</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">lignum pomiferum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:1:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Gen. 1, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">lignum scientiae boni et mali,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">lignum vitae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,027:2:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Apoc. 2, 9</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n26592.8" n="E" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A staff, club</hi> (eccl. Lat.): <cit><quote lang="la">cum gladiis et lignis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,002:14:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Marc. 14, 43</bibl></cit> and 48.</sense></entryFree>
